replies.text:
The following is from a BBC article from 2010:

Attempts to build a multicultural society in Germany have "utterly failed", Chancellor Angela Merkel says.
She said the so-called "multikulti" concept - where people would "live side-by-side" happily - did not work, and immigrants needed to do more to integrate - including learning German.
The comments come amid rising anti-immigration feeling in Germany.
A recent survey suggested more than 30% of people believed the country was "overrun by foreigners".
The study - by the Friedrich Ebert Foundation think-tank - also showed that roughly the same number thought that some 16 million of Germany's immigrants or people with foreign origins had come to the country for its social benefits.


Media captionThe German Chancellor, Angela Merkel: "lmmigrants should learn to speak German"
Attempts to build a multicultural society in Germany have "utterly failed", Chancellor Angela Merkel says.
She said the so-called "multikulti" concept - where people would "live side-by-side" happily - did not work, and immigrants needed to do more to integrate - including learning German.
The comments come amid rising anti-immigration feeling in Germany.
A recent survey suggested more than 30% of people believed the country was "overrun by foreigners".
The study - by the Friedrich Ebert Foundation think-tank - also showed that roughly the same number thought that some 16 million of Germany's immigrants or people with foreign origins had come to the country for its social benefits.


Foreign workers
Mrs Merkel told a gathering of younger members of her conservative Christian Democratic Union (CDU) party on Saturday that at "the beginning of the 60s our country called the foreign workers to come to Germany and now they live in our country."
She added: "We kidded ourselves a while, we said: 'They won't stay, sometime they will be gone', but this isn't reality."
"And of course, the approach [to build] a multicultural [society] and to live side-by-side and to enjoy each other... has failed, utterly failed."

Source: 
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-11559451

We are not talking about China resettling Hong Kong with more Han chinese to reduce the number of cantonese speakers, nor we are talking about a colonial elite imposing their culture in one of their colonies. replies.author: @adelahogarth2761
replies.text:
ThePunisher129 Anarcho-communism will win *eventually* ... complacency of revolutionary activity is the death knell of direct action, however. As it stands we have the capitalist ruling class thinking that they can own and privatize the very wealth of Earth and now they're trying to colonize and privatize the wealth of the Solar system rather that guaranteeing all humanity has an equal inheritance to space and the universe.

While it's correct to say without Earth, that can never be a reality--do you really want to wait for the Elon Musks of the world to steal more of humanity's birthright?

Sure, fascists will eventually face death. But they ain't going down without that inevitable fight that will require us to *actually fight* ...

Marxism tells us that a society does not alter its structuralist foundations and hierarchies of power while the productive forces of said hierarchy seek to allow it. 

For the same reasons the workers will inevitably win, is the same reason why the workers of the world must fight and sabotage society's productive forces in order to seek and cement actual change to the hierarchy.

Moreover the hierarchies of power is more than just capitalism. While everything is labour, so too is everything social capital and appeals to structuralism. Nietzsche was fundamentally, on some level, correct that while one cannot simply become the ubermensch--one can create the society from which the ubermensch shall be hypothetically born.

Communism is not an end goal, communism is about perpetual revolution againstÂ the solidification of class constructs.

This is why 'there is no peace under Marxism' ...Â  appeals to peace are appeals to artificial hierarchies of power. Even if we got rid of the police, the state, the capitalist ruling class--perpetual revolution against the solidification of class consciousness in order to maintain the fight against a new one emerging is key.

Direct action is synonymous with revolution... only the content and unsympathetic seek 'peace'.

replies.author: @catriona_drummond
replies.text:
I honestly struggle to think of anything even remotely a right wing as Breitbart in Germany. On a funny side note "Breitbart" is actually a legit German word meaning "wide beard"; we take it as a hint to waht neckbeards might contribute to it.
Anyway "Die Welt" aka "The World" is somewhat burgeois conservative, a bit law and order (for Germany that is), pro America and pro EU. Die Welt is also pretty pro Israel.
There are smaller publications that are somewhat more subversive and more to the right of it like "junge Freiheit" (young freedom) a neoliberal/market radical/libertarian/homo homini lupus est -  mix but its very much a niche. You might still find some positions in that that you will here form some rather business-friendly democrats in the US.
More towards the extreme right and a "worthy" German attempt at mimicking Breitbart levels of edginess and plain lies would probably be the magazine "COMPACT" which's (you should really have the word "which's" in English, its useful) main business is in massive fearmongering among a certain demographic. It's pretty marginal though, compared to any mainstream publications.
(this is my opinion anyway, other German's mileage my vary) For some with a more western german background and a left wing tradition of ideas reaching back to 1968, "die Welt" will be what the red cloth is to the bull. (As we say in a proverb)

replies.author: @thevisitor135
replies.text:
Alek Mitev >Nevermind the fact that all the best memes were always made by the rightwing, never the left or centrists
[citation needed]. If you want to make a statistical claim, ALWAYS first find a source, in order to not "talk out of your own ass" as people would say. Anecdotal ("My own experience" type) evidence doesn't count by the way. And regarding appropriations and alterations of pre-existing memes, well, the Pepe Frog, also known as #FeelsBadMan was initially just a innocuous picture of a humanoid frog either being sad or happy in reaction to a major event or simply a good joke/bad tragedy, until the /pol/acks came along and reappropriated it to fit their political agenda, such as having Pepe endorse Donald Trump, making him the emperor of "Kekistan", wearing SS uniforms, repeating /pol/ talking points or caricatures of Jews, etc, and it became EXTREMELY popular, so much so that the original creator had to put his foot down to attempt to "rip out" Pepe from the hands of the "alt-right" and bring it back to it's originalist roots, so meme reappropriation =/= low quality and stagnation in all cases, *especially when used to point out hypocrisy on either side of the aisle* (See the NPC meme details and how both extremes parrot the same points they are indoctrinated with).

replies.author: @thevisitor135
replies.text:
Alek Mitev >"Ok then someone is triggered I see"
>Any counterargument I get with just one word in it presented in caps = "triggering"
"Opposing arguments bad, words in caps bad, non-rightwing people bad"
Talk about pot calling the Kettle black. *Ok hand symbol goes here*  See how the NPC meme can go for both extremes in certain situations? That's what the OP of the comment meant to say, in one way or another.

replies.author: @thevisitor135
replies.text:
Alek Mitev I was always the type to be verbose or make a extensive rebuttal/counterargument/counterpoint to be honest, since a "simple, witty comment" alone does not in itself work in proper debates and may make you look like a "clueless dumbarse". Has nothing to do with "triggering" (Which would look something like this: "WAAAAAAA, MUH FEELINGS, OH YOU OFFENDED ME YOU LITTLE XYZ! GO AWAY, YE BIGOT/NAZI/RACIST/REACTIONARY REEEEEEEEEEEEEE, YOU DEVALUE OTHERS MEEEEEEEEEEEHHHHH", assuming we are following the typical example of a angry feminist), as that would by definition make me scream all over the place, hurl ad hominems and personal attacks at the opponent, or simply appeal to emotion or "clutch pearls". 

Anyways, regarding the whole "left vs right meme" debate or whose is better, generally speaking, memes are mostly apolitical and do not focus on any particular ideology, political party, or organization, and are simply there to spread info and comedy in a unorthodox and "made for internet" way, point out inconvenient truths in a tragicomic fashion, mock someone else's ridiculous gaffes, or simply use a  memorable soundbyte or scene from a movie and reproduce it to suit particular situations. 

The only "political" ones are mostly originating from outlets such as /pol/, /leftypol/, r/The_Donald, etc, and are not yet composing a clear majority of the general netsphere, and Harambe etc too wasn't political or tied to any particular "wing". A meme's quality depends on its originality, ability to amuse and be genuinely memorable, persist for a long time on the Internet, have a unique slogan and concrete message, and not "die off" within several months (Cough, Ugandan Knuckles, cough hnnng), not it's political agenda or what "wing" it belongs to. If it's crappy and political, it is crappy, no matter what wing it is tied to, and if it is good and apolitical or political then it is good, simple as that. Rate according to merit, not ideology or conflict of interest. My opinion and stance.

Concerning the bit starting at 8:12...
Three Arrows contradicts himself in epic fashion. He insists that Kalergi was not a globalist but then goes on to say that Kalergi sought to turn Africa into a mere slave colony for the benefit of Europe. 
Globalism is simply monopolistic competition among governments. It is the term to describe those who strive for a one-world-government. Absolving Africa of all its nation states and bringing them under a single authority fits globalism in the most literal sense. This Three Arrows guy is a disingenuous hack and propagandist. My condolences to anyone who takes his analysis as gospel.

replies.author: @somanytakennames
replies.text:
Hahaha, are you a friend of Iconoclast? You seem awfully emotional over his shortcomings being pointed out. 
Let's look at a couple of examples of his sources backfiring on him.

1. The most obvious one would be the graph he uses at 38:32. A graph he thought backed his idea that the increase of emigration of Germans was due to the migrants, when it literally indicates below the graph that it was due to the change in the method for gathering data. 

2. 26:29. Here he uses a Breitbart article. Which also unsurprisingly, took something Frank-Walter Steinmeier said out of context. And what a surprise, as we can see at 28:26, what he said wasn't anything like what Iconoclast and Breitbart suggested he said. 

3. 20:15. The Dali Lama's comments about Europe being for Europeans when that exact sentiment was shared by Kalergi, the man who Iconoclast claims doesn't think this. Also how claims on the "Globalist Left" were enraged by these comments when it clearly says in the article, "users on social media". 

So there, three solid examples of sources that Iconoclast used which actually hindered him more than helped. So Iconoclast either has a problem properly examining his sources, which is a bit of an issue if he's going to create this sort of content. Or he simply doesn't care and has no problem in manipulating his sources in order to make it look as though it fits in with his narrative. As we clearly seem him do at 42:04 when he takes things Kalergi said at different parts in his book and sticks them together in order to create some sort of quote that echoes what Iconoclast has been trying to say. Like a child in arts and crafts class. Either way, it's not exactly good. At least Three Arrows has the guts to actually list his sources so people can check what he said, unlike Iconoclast. Another reason I like this guy. 

So, if your previous comment is anything to go by, I look forward to reading your equally mature response. You seem like the sort of person who doesn't let their emotions get the better of them.

text: I'm an Iconoclast viewer and, not that I take all or even most of what he says to be true, I clicked on this video expecting to hate you, or at the very least disagree with you. But, I found that by the end most of my hatred was directed towards Iconoclast. I had always viewed his content as propaganda that was far more right-wing than I was and tended to take it with a grain of salt, but the degree to which he spreads misinformation is far beyond what I expected. I have found that type of information that I have been consuming is more and more right wing and this was something that I didn't notice until I watched you give a fairly centrist takedown of something that I had considered to be truthful video. So thanks for taking me out of my spiral towards fascism. I'll try to be more wary of what I watch in the future, it's amazing what a bit of research can tell you.

author: @kenshin6553
text: It's always fascinated me how these so-called "nationalists" are so concerned with other countries'  affairs. A Scottish guy telling Germany how it should define its national identity, Canadian Lauren Southern touring European countries to protest their immigration policies, etc. I think a better term for them would be pan-ethnonationalism--they don't just want ethnonationalism in their own nations, they want the entire world to share their ethnonationalist worldview. So in that sense, aren't these people holding a _globalist ideology_ ?

replies.author: @matthewmuir8884
replies.text: Interesting point. Just one quick thing I want to point out: he's not Scottish; apparently, he's English.

replies.author: @Slomowo
replies.text:
It's because we see a threat that is international *and* internationalist, therefore, we see a need to act internationally as well. As much as it is of the interest of internationalist groups to advocate and encourage internationalist movements in other countries, it is also of our interest to advocate and encourage nationalist groups in those other countries in order to have a proper counter against our adversaries' growth. For an instance, in countries where nationalist movements are bigger and more prominent, internationalist movements from outside usually encourage the growth of internationalist movements within such nations.
It's more about reason and strategy. It's not a globalist ideology, it's an international mindset.

replies.author: @kenshin6553
replies.text: @Slomowo Fair enough, but what if a country doesn't want to define itself ethno-nationally? What if the people of a country are, for whatever reason, in favor of immigration and feel it's serves their national interests? Whether you agree with their decision to do so or not, these ethnonationalists are putting themselves in a position where they're telling other nations how they should and shouldn't define their own national identity. Why are you concerned with other countries, instead of just fighting "globalism" in you own country?

replies.author: @Slomowo
replies.text:
@kenshin6553 I'm not only speaking of ethnonationalism, but okay. Still, the same serves to you, then what if a country wants to define itself as an ethnostate? Should I stop the internationalists from investing in minority internationalist movements in this country and argue they should work only in their national forms? They won't stop there, they will invest in movements of other places because their desire is to change people's minds. They're telling another nation how they should and shouldn't define their own national identity too, in your reasoning.

You cannot counter an international movement only in a national form, I tell this to people in my circles all the time, it's a historical fact. I'm not telling other people the specifics of how they should define their national identity, I'm just telling them to do away with civic nationalism in favor of integral nationalism. The internationalist movements are telling them to either adopt civic nationalism or internationalism as a whole. It's an ideological dispute; maybe at some point it might turn into actual physical, significant wars with the polarization going on, and I seriously hope it doesn't.

Donald Trump Sry, but just a few thoughts. Because this culture identity talk makes me angry.

Waht if we are all indiviuals and your "racial consciousness" is made up bullshit?

That the homogenisation you cry about is born from humans adopting the cultures, ethics and traits that benefit themselves the most, not the ones they were forced upon by their ancestors? That it is madness to force yourself to live like your ancestors if it is your life and yours alone?

I am confident enough to say my identity isnt based on the country I am from and who I am is not dependend on who my ancestors were, those fuckers are dead and have no right to demand anything of how I live my life, I'd rather go with what is most effective and provides the most joy for me individually and my peers, so thank you. text: About the migration background: since it's just a statement of citizenship of one of the parents it will also include a whole bunch of people whose parents are German and Austrian or German and Swiss despite those parents being ethnically and culturally more or less the same. replies.text: Yeah, there is also another study which measures Germany with "immigration background". So basically everyone who had a Silesian ancestor suddenly had "immigration background". You can imagine how hilariously high the percentage was.

Multiculturalism of the kind we see today is wrong, because it creates conflict in otherwise stable societies. Is this conflict justified? More often than not, no. But does that mean we should push through multiculturalism anyway and breed this conflict? No, it's a destructive force in our societies and never was anything but a bad idea. 

Multicultural societies are supposed to form NATURALLY (yes, they historically worked like this, for example Rome becoming a multicultural hub because of its grandure, fine. There are many examples of influential cities and places becoming multicultural, this is natural), not by actively importing people. ESPECIALLY not when most of the citizens are against this. This is asking for trouble. And you can create the conflict and afterwards argue that the conflict is not justified, but it's still your policies that created the conflicts. Like how we can blame certain African countries for their illogical ethnic disputes ravaging their countries... but it really was just us Europeans shoving them into one country within their consent. This is how humans work, accept that and stop this dumb idea of artificially created multiculturalism. It creates nothing but trouble.

@MK-qb7nj first lets start with some statistics. Germany has 83.02 million inhabitants of wich 11.23 million are "non germans". I put non germans in quotation marks because people with only a migrational backround also count in this statistic. That means someone half german and half french is counted as non german. 
So we see 13.53% of people living in germany are per definition non germans. 
Now lets look at these 13.53%:
13.21% of these 11.23 million are of Turkish origin. 7.72% are of Polish origin and 6.22% are of Syrian origin. The rest are f.e. from Italy, Irak, Geeece...
So the largest group of non germans makes up 1.79% of the total population (these are just my calculations, the highest number I found was 4.2%). The second largest group comes from one of the most cristian countries possible. 
If you use the "worst" predictions possible still 72.29% of germans are ethnic germans with no migrational backround. That looks like the majority to me. (And a big part of non germans are still from european countrys like Poland and France).
But you still have a point. Ethnic germans have less children than people f.e. from Turkey. But this is only on the case in the first generation. The longer they live in germany the closer they get to the average german. 
Now to the cultural aspect. It is fascinating to see how Muslims celebrate cristian traditions like Fastnacht. In fact religion is becoming less important in germany and all over the world. I'm not saying that I like that this is happening, but you have to see the good sides. Due to this german traditions are celebrated no matter what religion you are. And due to the Denkmalschutz old cathedrals and churches will be cared for and our traditions will live on. 

So what policies or laws would be useful? Motivation of Mothers to get more children. Thats the only one that could "help". Do you know who also motivated mothers to have as many children as possible to protect the german ethnicity? I hope you do. 

I hope you now see that we have no crisis here in germany. You are right germany is a very special place and many who want to move here soon find out that it might not be the country for them. 
We live our culture and the imigrants do not change us, we change them (in a cultural sense).

I have twenty dogs, which I use to pull my ploughs. They work hard and earn a lot of food, but their work hasn't left them much time to have any puppies. So I let them rest for a while so they can have more of a chance to start families. Meanwhile, my neighbour's farm burns down. While he's rebuilding, I take in ten horses and ten dogs from his farm and put them to work on my farm while my dogs rest. When my neighbour's farm is repaired, some of his animals go back to his farm, while some stay working on my farm, giving me a larger workforce in the process.

replies.author: @brandondavidson4085
replies.text: Jordan Gehall Wentsworth You didn't answer my last question at all, but I'll accept your opinions on the matter of the Zionist Movement. The Book of Revelations clearly states that there will be no peace in that area until the Second Coming of Christ, but the other historic thing to remember is that Britain and France were the ones who divided up the region after World War 2.  All of Europe and the Western world agreed to recognize Israel, while practically all of the Middle Eastern world agreed to deny their existence for decades; some still do, like Syria. Then, they all waged their own wars against this new nation of Israel, and every few years its borders change a little bit. I would highly recommend watching Knowing Better's video about the Middle East and the many conflicts there, in his video "Constantinople (Not Byzantium)... and the Rest of the Middle East".

replies.author: @brandondavidson4085
replies.text: Jordan Gehall Wentsworth You say "Back to the point" and then you start talking about something that I never mentioned. You can't redirect this conversation to "the Zionists" with this one. I said that alt-Right propagandists on YouTube amuse me because they don't even try that hard to hide their bigotry and hatred of Jewish people behind thinly-veiled anti-Jewish conspiracy theories. Even when they aren't explicitly making videos about these conspiracy theories, they reference extremist websites like The Daily Stormer or funnel their viewers towards other even more Fascist channels. author: @tomhall7633
text:
Here in the states as a working class bloke, I have known and worked with folks that would give credence to iconoclast's message solely because it reinforces rather than challenges their perceptions that immigrants are the cause of the decline in wages of working class jobs. I wish I could testify that it was a uninformed and xenophobic minority but it appears to be the prevailing notion (though not overwhelmingly so) among the white working class. As frustrating as it is to endure this level of willful ignorance, it is a powerful political weapon, silently assented to if not endorsed by lower management, and exploited with increasing subtlety and sophistication as you move up the management hierarchy.  It is important to ridicule bad reasoning especially when adopted to reach a preordained conclusion, but it is important to recognize that narratives not constrained by reality are cheaper and most easily edited for the passions of the moment than carefully constructed evidence based arguments.
As inconceivable as a Trump presidency seemed in the fall of 2016 (even from the cynical point of view that the plutocracy would never entrust their fortunes and futures to a narcissistic simpleton), fear, straw man barbarians at the gate, and the promise of return to a gentler time when everyone knew their place has been the successful formula to threaten the world and the planet.

author: @ValerieRaya
text:
"If you have brown skin some will never see you as a true German" That reminds me of my best friend, whose name is Lina (a common German name but also common Arabic name) but who was not born here (she is a German citizen and has been here since she was 5 and her younger sisters have traditional German names, one being Linda) and has an ArabicÂ surname. She is currently studying in Sachsen-Anhalt, a more right-wing part of the country. She isn't dark-skinned, and so is often 'mistaken for a German' by people who know her first name only. She recently had a group project with two people who have been German for many generations, Markus and Lisa, and one who was born here but his parents weren't, Ahmad. Markus had only seen the names on the paper, first names only, and decided he would not work with Ahmad, despite never having met him. He was fine with the two girls, but not Ahmad. Until they wrote their full names and he saw Lina's last name. He then refused to work with her as well and turned very rude, and only reluctantly worked with them under threat of failing class.
Lina also works in elderly care to pay for her expenses. Many elderly are racist there and she had people tell her that there are 'too many immigrants' working there (they should be happy anyone is willing to help and wash them and change their diapers imo) to which she only nods and when she's finished smiles and says "If you like me to do more, just ask for Miss Arabic" which usually shuts them up.
They also have one woman who knows Lina's not born here and still always complains about 'those dirty immigrants' to her and especially about one coworker, who is, as per my friend, 'an angel and as German as it can get', who has been German since at least 3 generations, but has a dark skin. The old woman calls her the 'black devil'. She loves my friend, though, because 'even though she's an immigrant, she's not one of *those*'.
Charming people, really.

author: @VemiX1000
text:
I literally cannot even fathom why some people are so obsessed with nationality, race, ethnicity and so on so forth and I am from Bosnia which is smack in the middle of ultra nationalism, ultra religiousness, ultra conservative and ultra everything else. Far be it from me to tell anyone how to feel or what to believe but personally while I understand the feeling of belonging one might get from identifying with a certain group the shear amount of overinflated importance it is put on it is just ridiculous. Nationalism is bad in my view but it does not worry me as it can be easily countered. What does wory me however, is the religious groups because often times the most fundamental members are impossible to talk to at all and tend to have violent tendencies which are only held back by law of the land and if a party that does not share ther views is in power or even if it is still has a strong opposition. 

Take Monte Negro as an example. They had an election recently and the people that won are pretty much absolute Orthodox Church loyalists. They are not officially in office yet and they already started threatening minorities with violence if they don't leave the country. In general my main worry is the tendency of such groups to simply act like no laws or boundaries exist at all and that their faith gives them the absolute right to do whatever they like without consequence.

author: @Shonras
text:
Besides the many lies of The Iconoclast video, the idea that only western countries undergo immigration and demographic changes, and having diversity is utterly false:

- The countries with the most immigrants are the Middle-Eastern ones, such as Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Koweit. In Qatar for instance the immigrants outnumber by far the Qatari. Of course this doesn't mean that immigrants are treated well, on the contrary, and this is a huge issue, but according to white supremacists the natives have been 'replaced'.

- South Africa has a black majority population with also white and asian minorities, being one of the african countries with the most immigrants.

- Many sub-saharian migrants come to Maghreb, and unfortunately they face discriminations. I even saw a morrocan guy fearing of being 'replaced' by sub-saharian population as most north african countries are close to achieve their demographic transition whilst sub-saharian countries aren't. Their own version of this stupid conspiracy theory of great replacement, I guess.

- By the past, Turkey welcomed many immigrants from the Balkans, and many arabic, kurds and blacks live in this country as well.

- Even Japan, which is an homogeneous country, decided to welcome recently more immigrants due to its ageing population.

- Technically speaking, South America is a very diverse continent with more 'mixed-race' than any other part of the world. Less than half of Brazilians identify themselves as "white", yet I never saw complaints about 'great replacement'. Perhaps this is just a matter of time before we finally accept it in Europe, I hope...

Furthermore, describing Europe as only 'white' and 'christian' is kinda reductive. What about Albanians, Bosnians and Chechenians for instance, being mainly muslims? And I can guarantee that without non-European immigrants, other European immigrants will receive prejudices instead of them. In the past (and still now) Eastern and Southern europeans suffered from discrimination. Irish and italians immigrations in the USA were considered as 'white niggers'... Where is this 'unified' continent, again?

And the rest are nowhere near comparable to what is happening in the west with the push of "Diversity" and literally undermining and destroying our civilization and forcing it onto us. No other country does this.

author: @swordofdamocles5846
text: Great video! I follow some of the anti-SJW YouTubers, and while I agree with them that there are problems with PC culture, especially in academia, I am so disgusted with the ethno nationalism, and the radicalisation of some of them. Keep it up

replies.author: @Jotakumon
replies.text:
To be honest, I'm doubting the SJW issues in academia as well. From personal experience, I've never encountered anything like it in several unis. As for non-anecdotal evidence, I don't have any, but the burden's on them, right? And I have yet to see some evidence that supports their claim that campuses are extremely left, or dominated by SJWism, or that a PC culture is present on them. They only present single incidents as evidence. It seems more and more likely to me that they're making this much bigger than it actually is (much like the things in the video).

Don't get me wrong, I'm against PC-culture as well, it's bad. But I'm less and less convinced that such a culture exists on campuses. And the claims and arguments that they do exist start to become oddly similar to the claims that rape culture supposedly exists on college campuses. Which I would also despise, but I don't see either really happening.

replies.author: @swordofdamocles5846
replies.text: @Jotakumon I go to university in Denmark, and while I have not experienced any problems studying political science, I have gone to a couple of lectures in sociology, where the narrative of patriarchy and criticism of western  civilization has been prevalent. I agree it is not widespread in other fields, however I fear it influencing policy in the long run. For example hate speech laws or gender/ racial quotas in firms being pushed from a feminist perspective by lobbying groups.

replies.author: @Jotakumon
replies.text:
@swordofdamocles5846 I understand, and I disagree with the content of that kind of speech. But it's important to notice that this is what free speech means, especially on campuses. A degree in sociology need to tackle those issues, regardless of their truthfulness. It doesn't necessarily mean that they defend those issues. Much like I, a capitalist, if talking about capitalism, will also mention its flaws, while also mentioning the advantages of communism. It doesn't mean that I am in favour of communism, or that I think it's great. And it's important that I allow communists to speak out and make their point, so I have more ammo to tell them how stupid they are, wink wink.

As for quotas, I'm am against them personally (at least in the long term), but I also think that people oversimplify things. There are pragmatic reasons for companies to use those quotas, going well beyond SJW talking points. Just because SJWs are also in favour of quotas, it doesn't make someone who is favour of quotas an SJW. Much like the Nazis privatising many sectors of the economy does not mean that anyone who's in favour of privatising some of those sectors is necessarily a Nazi. Someone who's in favour of universal healthcare might still be a capitalist, someone who cares about environmental politics is not necessarily left-wing, and someone who is for closed borders is not necessarily right-wing.

It seems obvious to me that feminists would be pushing those quotas, but it's not obvious that those quotas being implemented means that feminism was the reason for it. For almost any action and policy, you will find a group supporting that action or policy. But that action or policy being implemented does not mean that it's been done in response to that group's activism, or that it was the main driving force behind it.

But let me just say that I'm just as worried about SJWism as I assume you are. But I'm just not sure I'm seeing it as this massive problem that many people keep claiming exists. I see it occasionally, sometimes there's a bigger impact here or there, much like with racism. But I don't see any huge impact on our culture, and I think that most people who you rationally explain why SJWism or racism is bad, will agree rather quickly.

replies.author: @kakibackup2koujo612
replies.text: Joel Costa PC culture does exist but it is overblown by the anti sjw crowd.

replies.author: @Jotakumon
replies.text:
@kakibackup2koujo612 I think we disagree more in semantics than what's actually going on. I do think PC culture exists, in that it's an idea supported by enough people to consider those people as a group, even if only a minority. What I meant is that I don't see PC culture the way, as you precisely pointed out, the Anti-SJW crowd is presenting it. The sort of group that would participate in some mass hysteria and have huge influence over politics and culture. Not to say that they don't have any, but I don't see the larger impact. That is, again, how I perceive it.

I would add to that that if there is a culture I'm more worried about, it's what I'd describe as the bandwagon culture, or maybe the outrage culture. And I think SJWism and PC culture are mere effects or examples of that culture, as seems to be Anti-SJWism.

replies.author: @KommentarSpaltenKrieger
replies.text: Nah, there is more to it. I'm not an advocate of cultural politics since politics should be about straight-up things like education, economic welfare, workforce organization and such things, but reducing German culture to some foods and customs is only possible if you ignore a lot of stuff going on in this country, just like everywhere else. One cannot over-estimate the impact of German philosophers on the world, for example, dating to this day and age. If there is one thing I've noticed in the last couple of years it's the sheer amount of impact folks like Nietzsche, Hegel, Marx, Heidegger, Habermas, Adorno etc. have on the political discourse in the entire west and beyond. And this is only about philosophy. I'm far from being a cultural supremacist but there are some interesting things going on in Germany intellectually.

replies.author: @spad1782
replies.text:
thesatanic6 Not interested in getting into a "debate" so you can have the last say in this. Many of the things said by our friend the Iconoclast were pretty questionable from the start, and Three Arrows refutes most of his unfounded claims. I don't know what you mean by "evidence of racism" but (I'm making a generalization here, but given your antagonistic response to my comment I'm going to assume you fall into this boat, forgive me if I'm wrong) it seems like a lot of you far-right folk think that nothing is racist, hell, I get the impression that even if a black man was lynched by a gang of neo-Nazis today you fellas would start talking about black crime statistics. I take issue with first of all the almost baseless claims the Iconoclast makes to fear-monger and his comments throughout implying (and sometimes downright pretty much stating) that to be German you have to be white and Christian. So he cares more about (in Three Arrows words) "some weird blood purity" (keeping Germany white) than preserving German culture. If the culture is preserved, who gives a fuck about race? And also I doubt the Iconoclast would be able to tell the difference between a native German and some Frenchman that immigrated to Berlin to """leech off hardworking Germans"""". So yeah, it's a race thing. And the constant "Jews rule the world" implication is pretty bigoted (and a bit frightening I'm honest) to say the least. Also, if "real" Germans are white, then almost no one in America is a "real American." But I guess we're not talking about real ethnic genocides here.
I'm not saying there are some assimilation problems facing Europe. But look at America for an example, most of it's older immigrants (Asian, Indians, Europeans) are a benefit to it's society. It's unrealistic to think immigrants will suddenly become culturally German the minute they get there.

author: @soso-zz9qf
text:
I would love for you to look into my city, Toronto. It spits in the face of all of these right wing reactionaries claiming that migrants will destroy culture. My city is 51.1% visible minorities with a heck of a lot more white minority groups. According to reactionaries, Toronto should be crime ridden (it is one of the safest cities in North America ranked 4th in the world in 2017 on the Safe cities Index), unemployment should be rampant (our rate is 6.9% which is admittedly the highest in Ontario  but compared to the provincial average of 5.9% and considering that immigrants make up the majority of that number it's not too bad), and we should be devoid of culture (which is ridiculous; you can quite literally find anything from almost any culture in the world here). 

Another thing is that assimilation is discouraged in Canada, so each culture has its own little pocket. It's funny how this has not led to the destruction of the Canadian identity.
